author: By Glenn Thrush
title: Kaczynski Is Said to Have Died by Suicide in Prison
description: The man known as the “Unabomber” had been transferred to a federal prison medical center in 2021 after more than 25 years at a maximum security facility.
content: Theodore J. Kaczynski, the “Unabomber,” who killed three people and injured 23 in a bombing spree stretching from 1978 to 1995, died by suicide at a federal prison medical center in North Carolina early Saturday, according to three people familiar with the situation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Remy Tumin
title: Greta Thunberg Ends Her School Strikes After 251 Weeks
description: The climate activist, who has inspired young people around the world to demand action against climate change, graduated from high school on Friday in Sweden.
content: For five years, Greta Thunberg has spent her Fridays in front of the Swedish Parliament in Stockholm instead of in class; after 251 weeks, she is hanging up her cardboard protest sign — as a student.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shannon Sims
title: A New Era of Wedding Dress Shopping
description: As more brides seek personalized shopping experiences and multiple distinctive designs, the bridal industry is shifting to accommodate them.
content: Four months before Ashley Moore’s April 2023 wedding, she still didn’t have a wedding dress. After hours of searching, and even buying and returning a gown she’d changed her mind about, she finally fell in love with a dress she found at a department store. But what she didn’t love was the price. So Ms. Moore scoured the internet and eventually found the same gown being sold online for less at Mytheresa, a luxury fashion company.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: June 10, 2023
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Saturday, June 10, 2023.
content: An article on Friday about evidence found in phone messages that led to the downfall of Milo Djukanovic, the former president of Montenegro, misspelled the family name of a defense attorney. He is Mr. Begovic not Mr. Becovic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Binyamin Appelbaum and Reva Keller
title: Giving Red America a Reason to Love Electric Vehicles
description: Federal investment that gives people an economic stake in green energy may be the nation’s best chance to build a consensus to confront global warming.
content: Electric vehicles are rare in Moses Lake, Wash., a small city in the fertile Columbia Basin about a three-hour drive east of Seattle. In that conservative farms-and-factories community, few people have the cash or the inclination. The only electric vehicle I saw during a two-day visit last month was a Tesla in the hotel parking lot.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Nehamas and Jonathan Weisman
title: Carefully, Backhandedly, DeSantis Comes to Trump’s Defense
description: In a speech in North Carolina, Ron DeSantis drew on his experience as a Navy lawyer and suggested that either both Donald Trump and Hillary Clinton should have been indicted — or neither.
content: Visitors from a foreign planet might think Gov. Ron DeSantis of Florida had been delivered a tremendous gift this week when his main presidential rival was charged with mishandling the country’s national security secrets.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Conor Dougherty
title: The Hottest Thing in Real Estate Is a Loan From Two Years Ago
description: Real estate agents are pushing sub-3 percent mortgages as an amenity, just like marble countertops or a view of the mountains.
content: The only goal was to not lose money.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Kristof
title: Turning the Tide on Animal Suffering
description: Peter Singer and the modern animal rights movement have had a global impact — but there’s so much left to do.
content: In 1971, a half-dozen graduate students at Oxford University held what was perhaps the first protest of the modern animal rights movement. They insisted that respecting animals was a moral imperative.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lauren Hirsch and Michael J. de la Merced
title: After LIV Golf, What Will Be the Next Saudi Sports Bet?
description: The kingdom’s enormous sovereign wealth fund, which backed the golf series, has an appetite for sports. Its deal with the PGA Tour may pave the way for more investments.
content: When the Saudi Arabian-backed LIV Golf series announced an agreement to join with the PGA Tour on Tuesday, it shocked deal makers across the sports world.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Keh
title: Why Do Team Owners Raise the Championship Trophy First?
description: It’s a decidedly American tradition, even if it can be a buzz-kill.
content: What an ending. Your favorite N.B.A. team has just clinched a championship. The superstar, drenched in sweat, fulfilled his hero’s journey. The players are exhausted, but jubilant. Some of them are crying.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Corbin
title: Today’s Wordle Review
description: Our columnist reviews the day’s puzzle. Warning: Contains spoilers!
content: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This article contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lauren McCarthy
title: Suspect in Natalee Holloway’s Death Pleads Not Guilty to Extorting Her Mother
description: More than a decade after being indicted by the United States for wire fraud and extortion, Joran van der Sloot was arraigned in Alabama.
content: Joran van der Sloot, who has been linked to the 2005 disappearance of an American teenager, Natalee Holloway, pleaded not guilty to extortion and fraud charges in court in Birmingham, Ala., on Friday after he was temporarily extradited from Peru to the United States.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Futterman
title: Iga Swiatek, With an Enthralling Duel, Captures Another French Open Trophy
description: Swiatek was drawn into a tight match with Karolina Muchova, and emerged with her third singles championship at Roland Garros in four years.
content: Iga Swiatek is once more the queen of clay.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rachel Fairbank
title: A 20-Minute Boxing Workout to Build Strength and Endurance
description: One short workout can help you build fitness, achieve better balance and even ward off injuries. No punching bag needed.
content: Walking into a boxing gym can be an assault on the senses, whether it’s the ringing of a bell, the smell of accumulated sweat or the quick rat-a-tat of the speed bag.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charlie Savage
title: Trump Appointee Will Remain Judge in Documents Case, Clerk Says
description: The chief clerk of the courts for the Southern District of Florida added that Judge Aileen M. Cannon had been randomly assigned to the case.
content: The criminal case against President Donald J. Trump over his hoarding of classified documents was randomly assigned to Judge Aileen M. Cannon, a court official for the Southern District of Florida said on Saturday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Cade Metz
title: How Could A.I. Destroy Humanity?
description: Researchers and industry leaders have warned that A.I. could pose an existential risk to humanity. But they’ve been light on the details.
content: Last month, hundreds of well-known people in the world of artificial intelligence signed an open letter warning that A.I. could one day destroy humanity.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ross Douthat
title: Does the U.S. Government Want You to Believe in U.F.O.s?
description: Are there crashed alien ships kept hidden in hangars?
content: In U.F.O. arcana, one of the figures claiming a whistle-blower’s knowledge of a secret U.S. program to reverse-engineer recovered alien technology is a man named Bob Lazar.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Genevieve Glatsky
title: 4 Missing Children Found Alive After 40 Days in Colombian Jungle
description: Rescuers had been searching for the children — aged 13, 9, 4 and 1 — ever since they survived a plane crash that killed the three adults on board.
content: After 40 days in the Colombian rainforest, all four children who had been missing since the plane they were traveling in crashed on May 1 have been found alive, according to Colombia’s president.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Moscatello
title: Robert F. Kennedy Jr. Wants to Be President. Cheryl Hines Is Along for the Ride.
description: The “Curb Your Enthusiasm” actress is beloved in Hollywood. In supporting her husband’s campaign, is she normalizing his often dangerous ideas?
content: On a quiet Thursday in May, there was almost no indication that anyone in Cheryl Hines’s house was running for president. A hockey stick poked out from a bush in front of the Spanish colonial home in the Brentwood neighborhood of Los Angeles. Leaning up against a wall outside were several surfboards, caked with wax, at least one of which belonged to her husband, the 69-year-old environmental lawyer and vaccine skeptic Robert F. Kennedy Jr., who had announced his candidacy for the 2024 Democratic nomination only four weeks earlier.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Casey
title: The Spy Who Called Me
description: For years, Spanish society has been rocked by revelations from the secret tapes of José Manuel Villarejo Pérez, a former intelligence agent now facing prison. He told me his story.
content: The wave of scandals that would engulf Spain began with a police raid on a wooded property outside Madrid. It was Nov. 3, 2017, and the target was José Manuel Villarejo Pérez, a former government spy. Villarejo’s name had been circulating in the Spanish press for years. He was rumored to have had powerful friends and to have kept dirt on them all. The impressive variety of allegations against him — forgery, bribery, extortion, influence peddling — had earned him the nickname “king of the sewers.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chris Kornelis
title: Saycon Sengbloh Unwinds With Lo-Fi YouTube and Fireplace Vibes
description: The “Wonder Years” star takes care of herself with satin pillows, costume dramas and food that connects her to her Liberian roots.
content: When Saycon Sengbloh tried out for the role of Lillian Williams, the matriarch in ABC’s reboot of “The Wonder Years,” she was also auditioning to be her boss’s mother. The showrunner, Saladin K. Patterson, had decided that if he was going to remake the beloved sitcom — this time looking at the late 1960s through the lens of a Black family in Alabama — he was going to base the show loosely on his own family, starting with his parents, Bill and Lillian.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabetta Povoledo
title: Pope’s Doctors Say He’s on the Mend, but Advise Rest and No Events
description: Francis, who had abdominal surgery on Wednesday, has been advised by his medical team to rest and not recite his usual weekly prayer from his hospital balcony on Sunday.
content: Pope Francis is recovering well after undergoing abdominal surgery this past week, his surgeon said on Saturday, but his doctors advised him not to give his traditional public blessing on Sunday so that he can rest.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Is Masculinity in Crisis?
description: Readers discuss a column by David French about the virtues of masculinity and how they get distorted.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dan Bilefsky and Ian Austen
title: What to Know About Canada’s Exceptional Wildfire Season
description: Wild fires started earlier, are higher in number and spread across much of the country, burning millions of acres as climate change turns more of the country’s forest into a tinderbox.
content: Canada is burning.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Weisman
title: Chris Christie says he found the case laid out in the indictment ‘devastating.’
description: The former New Jersey governor and federal prosecutor said he expected criticism from his fellow Republicans to grow.
content: Chris Christie, the former Republican governor of New Jersey who is now running for president, called the facts in the indictment against his former ally Donald J. Trump “devastating,” and said that the small group of Republicans now critical of the former president’s conduct would grow.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Hubbard
title: From ‘Pariah’ to Partner, Saudi Leader Defies Threats to Isolate Him
description: Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman has repeatedly leveraged Saudi Arabia’s wealth and influence to overcome international condemnation of the kingdom’s human rights violations.
content: President Biden vowed during his quest for the White House to make the Saudi crown prince, Mohammed bin Salman, a “pariah” over the killing and dismemberment of a dissident. He threatened the prince again last fall with “consequences” for defying American wishes on oil policy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesus Jiménez
title: Toronto Blue Jays Cut Player Who Defended Anti-Queer Post
description: Anthony Bass had reposted a video on social media that called for a boycott of L.G.B.T.Q.-friendly companies.
content: The Toronto Blue Jays cut pitcher Anthony Bass, 35, on Friday, after he drew backlash and boos from fans for reposting a video on Instagram that called Target and Bud Light “evil” and “demonic” for being supportive of the L.G.B.T.Q. community.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Sandomir
title: Edward Stack, 88, Longtime President of the Baseball Hall of Fame, Dies
description: He presided over the annual Hall induction ceremony in Cooperstown, N.Y., for many years. But he also helped keep one star, Pete Rose, from being part of it.
content: Edward Stack, who as the president of the National Baseball Hall of Fame conceived the eligibility rule that continues to prevent the election of Pete Rose, the prolific hitter who had been banned from Major League Baseball for gambling, died on Sunday in Port Washington, N.Y., on Long Island. He was 88.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julian E. Barnes and Steven Erlanger
title: As Ukraine Launches Counteroffensive, Definitions of ‘Success’ Vary
description: Privately, U.S. and European officials concede that pushing all of Russia’s forces out of occupied Ukrainian land is highly unlikely.
content: After months of anticipation, Ukraine’s forces — newly trained on complex warfare tactics and armed with billions of dollars in sophisticated Western weaponry — launched operations on multiple fronts in the past week in an effort to dislodge entrenched Russian military units, a counteroffensive that many officials in the United States and Europe say could be a turning point in the 15-month war.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Javier C. Hernández
title: Opera About Refugee Children to Premiere at Spoleto Festival
description: “Ruinous Gods,” an exploration of the trauma of mass displacement, will be staged in Charleston, S.C., next year.
content: A chamber opera about refugee children and the trauma of mass displacement will premiere next year at Spoleto Festival USA, the organization in Charleston, S.C., announced on Saturday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Baker
title: Trump’s Case Puts the Justice System on Trial, in a Test of Public Credibility
description: The former president’s efforts to defend against multiple felony counts by discrediting law enforcement pose a grave challenge to democracy.
content: Former President Donald J. Trump has a lot at stake in the federal criminal case lodged against him. He could, in theory, go to prison for years. But if he winds up in the dock in front of a jury, it is no exaggeration to suggest that American justice will be on trial as well.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Blinder, Lauren Hirsch, Kevin Draper and Kate Kelly
title: Secrecy, Cigars and a Venetian Wedding: How the PGA Tour Made a Deal with Saudi Arabia
description: The agreement to remake a global game stunned most of the sporting world after seven weeks of clandestine negotiations.
content: Jay Monahan, the PGA Tour commissioner, had gone unnoticed in Venice last month.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anthony Tommasini
title: Masterpieces Galore: When Mozart Met the Enlightenment
description: In Patrick Mackie’s “Mozart in Motion,” the socially observant composer embraces modernity.
content: Musicians tend to be wary of ascribing specific meanings to music or making too much of a piece’s extra-musical associations. In one of his Norton Lectures at Harvard in 1973, turning to Beethoven’s “Pastoral” Symphony, Leonard Bernstein asked the audience to forget all about “birds and brooks and rustic pleasures” and instead concentrate on “pure” music. He then demonstrated how every phrase of the entire first movement is derived from little motifs of notes and rhythms in the first four bars of the score.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Haberman and Alan Feuer
title: Unanswered in Indictment’s Details on Trump’s Hoarding of Documents: Why?
description: The charging document offers some possible hints but does not establish that the former president had a goal beyond simply possessing the material.
content: For all the detailed evidence laid out in the 38-count indictment accusing former President Donald J. Trump of holding onto hundreds of classified documents and then obstructing the government’s efforts to retrieve them, one mystery remains: Why did he take them and fight so hard to keep them?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ed Shanahan
title: One Last Job? 60-Somethings With Mob Ties Charged in Jewel Heists
description: Four older men with extensive criminal records, including killings and a jailbreak, were charged this week in two brazen armed robberies in Manhattan.
content: When four men were charged this week in the brazen armed robberies of two Manhattan jewelers, their ages suggested it might not be their first encounter with the criminal justice system.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jessica Grose
title: It’s Not Just Men and Boys Who Are Struggling Right Now
description: Don’t forget about the women dying deaths of despair.
content: There’s been a lot of chatter lately about the Problem With Men. Several books have been published that focus on the declining fortunes of American males — notably Richard Reeves’s “Of Boys and Men” and Senator Josh Hawley’s “Manhood.” As summarized by my colleagues on their new podcast “Matter of Opinion”: Men are less likely to graduate from college now, they’re lonely, they’re more likely to die deaths of despair, grapple with alcohol and drug abuse, and they’re participating less in the labor market.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Garrett Schumann
title: What Happens When A.I. Enters the Concert Hall
description: Artificial intelligence is not new to classical music. But its recent, rapid developments have composers worried, and intrigued.
content: When the composer and vocalist Jen Wang took the stage at the Monk Space in Los Angeles to perform Alvin Lucier’s “The Duke of York” (1971) earlier this year, she sang with a digital rendition of her voice, synthesized by artificial intelligence.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lauren McCarthy
title: Michael Batayeh, Comedian and ‘Breaking Bad’ Actor, Dies at 52
description: Mr. Batayeh starred in three episodes of the Emmy-winning series and performed stand-up comedy.
content: Michael Batayeh, an actor best known for his brief role in the Emmy-winning series “Breaking Bad” and a comedian who was popular in the Arab-American community, died at his home in Ypsilanti, Mich. He was 52.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Baker
title: Inside the Hunt for the Idaho Killer
description: After four students were stabbed to death in a house near a college campus, investigators scooped up data and forensic evidence, hoping for leads. A new DNA technique finally brought a breakthrough.
content: In the weeks after four University of Idaho students were found slaughtered in a house near campus last November, a growing roster of investigators desperately searching for answers had yet to identify a suspect or even find the murder weapon.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robert Langellier and Terra Fondriest
title: When Chopping Down Trees Is a Gift to the Environment
description: We can’t afford to rob biodiversity to pay for the climate.
content: EMINENCE, Mo. — As dawn cracked one morning in mid-May, the botanist Neal Humke and I hiked up a hill eager to check on a landscape in progress. Five years ago, we cut nearly every single tree across 19 acres here, piled and burned the limbs and left the trunks where they lay. The goal was to restore one of the Ozarks’ rarest ecosystems, a type of dry, rocky grassland known as a glade. To bring back the grass, we had to clear it of trees.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eve Washington, Josh Katz and Tom Giratikanon
title: Top 10 Hardest and Easiest Spelling Bee Words, June 3-June 9
description: Most players cracked the code, but there was one tough bird.
content: Note: If you plan to play Spelling Bee’s Past Puzzles from the last week, this list may contain spoilers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Kessler
title: The A.I. Revolution Will Change Work. Nobody Agrees How.
description: The tally of how many jobs will be “affected by” world-changing technology is different depending on who you ask.
content: In 2013, researchers at Oxford University published a startling number about the future of work: 47 percent of all United States jobs, they estimated, were “at risk” of automation “over some unspecified number of years, perhaps a decade or two.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Paulson
title: How to Watch the Tony Awards
description: Here is all the information you’ll need to tune in on Sunday to the annual ceremony honoring Broadway’s top productions and performers.
content: When are the Tony Awards? We’re so glad you asked!
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aurelien Breeden
title: Syrian Refugee Charged With Attempted Murder After Stabbing in France
description: A local prosecutor said that the six victims of the attack, two adults and four very young children, were no longer in life-threatening conditions.
content: A homeless Syrian man in his 30s was charged with attempted murder and detained in France on Saturday in connection with a violent stabbing attack this past week that injured two adults and four young children, a prosecutor said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ian Austen
title: Orange and Smoky Skies Over a Province That Rolled Back Climate Measures
description: Doug Ford, Ontario’s premier, has a long history of opposition to renewable energy programs and an agenda that favors highway construction.
content: This was a week when residents of the three largest cities in Eastern Canada — Ottawa, Toronto and Montreal — experienced a phenomenon that has become all too familiar to anyone who lives in Vancouver, Edmonton and Calgary.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carol Rosenberg
title: Appeals Panel Is Examining Guantánamo Judge’s Next Job on Ethics Grounds
description: The issue has cast a cloud over the coming proceedings in the U.S.S. Cole bombing case, which are scheduled to last three weeks starting Monday.
content: An appeals panel on Friday limited the authority of the judge presiding in hearings in the U.S.S. Cole bombing case while it considers an ethics challenge, the latest obstacle in the slow-moving path to trial in the longest-running war crimes prosecution at Guantánamo Bay.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew E. Kramer
title: With Probes of Russian Lines, Ukraine’s Counteroffensive Takes Shape
description: Ukraine is using its new arsenal of Western tanks and armored vehicles in what is expected to be one of the largest military operations in Europe since World War II.
content: In the south, Ukrainian soldiers are fighting on an unforgiving landscape, table-flat farmland with little cover for troops trying to advance.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Livia Albeck-Ripka
title: How the Case Against Ted Kaczynski, the ‘Unabomber,’ Unfolded
description: The domestic terrorist, who evaded authorities for almost 20 years, killed three people and injured 23 others with his homemade bombs.
content: Ted Kaczynski, the confessed killer who attacked academics, business officials and others over nearly 20 years and became known as the Unabomber, died by suicide on Saturday at a federal prison in Butner, N.C., according to three people familiar with the situation. He was 81.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Landler
title: Boris Johnson’s Comeback Hopes May Be Dimmer Than He Thinks
description: The former British prime minister, who resigned from Parliament on Friday, has found his way back into voters’ good graces before. But analysts say there is now almost no plausible path back to power for him.
content: It is tempting to view Boris Johnson’s sudden resignation from Britain’s Parliament on Friday evening as merely another twist in a serpentine career, a tactical retreat rather than a political epitaph.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Genevieve Glatsky
title: Colombia’s Mustard Lovers Grow Desperate Amid Saucy Shortage of Dijon
description: Colombians are scrambling to find the beloved French condiment as a new health law removes it from shelves, leaving a tangy void in their hearts and sandwiches.
content: In Colombia, a new illicit product is on the rise. Desperate consumers are sneaking it in suitcases from abroad, hoarding it in their homes, paying outrageous prices online and lining up at clandestine locations to buy it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Glenn Thrush, Maggie Haberman and Alan Feuer
title: Trump Put National Secrets at Risk, Prosecutors Say in Historic Indictment
description: The indictment details evidence that the former president placed national security secrets in jeopardy and schemed to thwart the investigation into the matter.
content: Federal prosecutors laid out an evidence-packed case in an indictment unsealed on Friday that former President Donald J. Trump had put national security secrets at risk by mishandling classified documents he took from the White House and then schemed to block the government from reclaiming the material.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Traub
title: Ted Kaczynski, ‘Unabomber’ Who Attacked Modern Life, Dies at 81
description: Alone in a shack in the Montana wilderness, he fashioned homemade bombs and launched a violent one-man campaign to destroy industrial society.
content: Theodore J. Kaczynski, the so-called Unabomber, who attacked academics, businessmen and random civilians with homemade bombs from 1978 to 1995, killing three people and injuring 23 with the stated goal of fomenting the collapse of the modern social order — a violent spree that ended after what was often described as the longest and most costly manhunt in American history — died on Saturday in a federal prison medical center in Butner, N.C. He was 81.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joe Drape and Melissa Hoppert
title: Expert Picks: Who Will Win the Belmont Stakes?
description: Joe Drape and Melissa Hoppert assess the contenders for the 155th Belmont Stakes on Saturday.
content: National Treasure, coming off a victory in the Preakness Stakes on May 20, will try to add another leg of the Triple Crown to his résumé with a win in the 155th Belmont Stakes on Saturday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reuters
title: About 27 Killed, Mostly Children, When Mortar Shell Explodes in Somalia
description: A previously unexploded mortar shell went off as children were playing around it in a city in southern Somalia.
content: A mortar shell explosion near Qoryoley, a city in the Lower Shabelle region of southern Somalia, killed about 27 people, mainly children, and injured 53 on Friday, according to the state news agency.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Rogers
title: At Pride Event, Biden Vows to Protect Rights of L.G.B.T.Q. Americans
description: “This administration has your back,” the president told a group of Pride Month revelers outside the White House.
content: Standing on a stage decorated with rainbows and speaking to a crowd that included survivors of gay nightclub shootings and transgender rights advocates, President Biden on Saturday said his administration would work to counter a recent series of Republican-led bills and laws targeting the L.G.B.T.Q. community.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Hoppert
title: Secretariat’s Legend Rolls on Like, Well, a Tremendous Machine
description: Fifty years after Secretariat clinched the Triple Crown with a runaway win in the Belmont Stakes, fans still long to connect with his story.
content: It was a performance for the ages, growing more mythic as time goes on. Having won the Kentucky Derby and the Preakness Stakes in record fashion, Secretariat rocketed out of the starting gate on June 9, 1973 — his best start yet — and never let up. He moved “liked a tremendous machine,” as the announcer Chic Anderson put it, and crushed his competition by a whopping 31 lengths to win the Belmont Stakes on an uncomfortably warm but utterly joyous afternoon at Belmont Park.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marc Santora
title: Zelensky Signals Ukraine’s Counteroffensive Has Begun
description: As waters from the flooding of a burst dam began to recede, Ukrainian forces were trying to break through stout Russian defenses in the south and east.
content: President Volodymyr Zelensky on Saturday offered the strongest confirmation yet that the long-anticipated Ukrainian counteroffensive had begun, as battles along a 600-mile front line offered further evidence that the long-awaited counterattack was underway.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michelle Ruiz
title: People We Meet on Vacation
description: In her debut novel, “You Can’t Stay Here Forever,” Katherine Lin follows a young widow and her best friend to the French Riviera.
content: The Shady Husband Mystery is its own literary subgenre, in which industrious wives unspool their missing or otherwise absent spouses’ misdeeds. Notable titles include Laura Dave’s best seller turned Apple TV+ series, “The Last Thing He Told Me,” and Liane Moriarty’s “The Husband’s Secret.” Katherine Lin enters the canon with her debut novel, “You Can’t Stay Here Forever,” which opens with the consummate “good girl” attorney Ellie Huang Anderson smarting from the sudden loss of her “golden boy” husband, Ian Anderson, in a car accident.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Leonhardt
title: Trump’s Indictment Is Unavoidably Political
description: The prosecutors’ audience is not only the judge and jurors. It is also the American public.
content: The public filings in most legal cases are of secondary importance. What happens in the courtroom matters far more. But the United States of America v. Donald J. Trump is obviously not a typical case.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Genevieve Glatsky
title: Colombian Children Rescued From Jungle Are Said to Be in Good Health
description: The four siblings, ages 1 to 13, were eager to play and asked for books just a day after being rescued and having survived 40 days in the jungle, officials said.
content: Four Colombian children who survived in the Colombian jungle for 40 days after their plane crashed were eager to play and asked for books to read, officials said on Saturday, one day after the group was rescued.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ronda Kaysen
title: How Do I Force a Developer to Finish Construction Work in My Building?
description: Legally, a developer doesn’t need to finish the common areas in a building to start selling apartments. But there is pressure you can apply.
content: Q: Last year I bought a condo in a brand-new six-unit building in Brooklyn. The common areas were still under construction when I closed. Fourteen months later, this work is still not done. My neighbors and I continue to press the developer, and periodically he’ll send a few workers to do a half day of work, hardly sufficient to finish the job. The developer still controls the board, but another apartment is under contract and if the sale closes, the owners will control the board. How can we persuade him to finish the work?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Really Relish
description: Savor drifting through this record-setting Sunday puzzle by Sam Ezersky.
content: SUNDAY PUZZLE — Sam Ezersky is the digital puzzles editor for The New York Times; besides helping with the crossword, he oversees other games like Spelling Bee and Letter Boxed. This themeless grid, Sam’s favorite type to construct, is his 40th puzzle for The Times. It has only 118 entries, which is the lowest word count in Sunday puzzle history. On top of that, nearly a quarter of those entries have never appeared in a grid before. Sam likes a challenge, and when you see his byline on a puzzle, he wants you to think: Oh boy, time to buckle up!
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Karoun Demirjian and Edward Wong
title: China Has Had a Spy Base in Cuba for Years, U.S. Official Says
description: It was unclear whether the report might complicate Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken’s rescheduled trip to Beijing for meetings that begin June 18.
content: A Chinese spy base in Cuba that could intercept electronic signals from nearby U.S. military and commercial buildings has been up and running since or before 2019, when the Chinese base was upgraded, according to a Biden administration official.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joe Drape
title: Arcangelo’s Belmont Victory Makes Trainer First Woman to Win a Triple Crown Race
description: Jena Antonucci became the first female trainer to win a Triple Crown race, a series that spans more than a century. “I wish more people can be like horses,” she said.
content: As the field for the 155th running of the Belmont Stakes edged into the starting gate on Saturday, anyone who has been enthralled with this sport and everyone who loves thoroughbreds was hoping — no, pleading — for something good to happen.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maureen Dowd
title: Bathroom Reading at Mar-a-Lago
description: Let’s Make America Great Again — by getting Trump out of politics.
content: WASHINGTON — It’s shocking how easy it is to imagine Donald Trump campaigning for the presidency from prison.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tanya Gold
title: Harry Is a More Interesting Prince Than We Deserved
description: He is not the first royal to give evidence. But he is the first to go to court to seek revenge for his life.
content: CORNWALL, England — The urge to fictionalize Prince Harry is addictive. If you are a monarchist, that is what he is for. For the last few years he’s been trying to reclaim himself from our imagined account. Most recently in court 15 in the Rolls Building, London, earlier this week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Hart
title: Science Fiction From Latin America, With Zombie Dissidents and Aliens in the Amazon
description: A new wave of writers is making the genre its own, rooting it in local homelands and histories.
content: A spaceship lands near a small town in the Amazon, leaving the local government to manage an alien invasion. Dissidents who disappeared during a military dictatorship return years later as zombies. Bodies suddenly begin to fuse upon physical contact, forcing Colombians to navigate newly dangerous salsa bars and FARC guerrillas who have merged with tropical birds.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ian Prasad Philbrick and Tom Wright-Piersanti
title: A.I. or Nuclear Weapons: Can You Tell These Quotes Apart?
description: Many experts on artificial intelligence are warning of its potential dangers and calling for regulation, just as others once did with the atomic bomb.
content: The comparison seems to be everywhere these days. “It’s like nuclear weapons,” a pioneering artificial intelligence researcher has said. Top A.I. executives have likened their product to nuclear energy. And a group of industry leaders warned last week that A.I. technology could pose an existential threat to humanity, on par with nuclear war.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: In South Florida, a Packed Calendar Is Reason to Cheer
description: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, June 10, 2023.
content: “I was very pessimistic when the playoffs began. But we’ve come to realize it’s all about the playoffs. You gotta enjoy it. You only get one chance.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Audio
title: Listen Early to This American Life: Must Be Rats on the Brain
description: And the best of the archive, found in our new audio app.
content: The New York Times Audio app includes podcasts, narrated articles from the newsroom and other publishers, and exclusive new shows that we’re making available to readers for a limited time. Download the audio app here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Tough to Grasp
description: Find some time for John Hawksley’s heavy-duty themeless puzzle.
content: SATURDAY PUZZLE — This is a beautiful and imposing grid from John Hawksley, who has constructed three previous puzzles for The Times, and they all have interesting geometry. This one’s wide-open center, composed of stacks of five 11-word entries in both the acrosses and the downs, is quite a centerpiece, and nine of those 10 entries are debuts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Damien Cave
title: Worldwide, Trump’s Latest Legal Woes Draw Outrage, and Shrugs
description: Allies and rivals alike, beholding the messiness of America, must calculate the risks and opportunities in the latest plot twist in Donald Trump’s legal troubles.
content: As details emerged from the indictment charging former President Donald J. Trump with mishandling classified documents, global reaction ranged from strategic silence to unbridled outrage, with room in between for world-weary shrugs, wild conspiracy theories and ominous predictions of American decline.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Swan, Maggie Haberman and Nicholas Nehamas
title: ‘This Is the Final Battle’: Trump Casts His Campaign as an Existential Fight Against His Critics
description: Donald J. Trump delivered his first post-indictment public remarks on Saturday at the state G.O.P. conventions in Georgia and North Carolina, as his federal indictment dominates the political landscape.
content: Former President Donald J. Trump on Saturday cast both his indictments by prosecutors and his bid for the White House as part of a “final battle” with “corrupt” forces that he maintained are destroying the country.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Scott Cacciola
title: The Heat Say They Love Adversity. They Must Be Happy Now.
description: Only one team has come back from a 3-1 series deficit in the N.B.A. finals, but the Miami Heat seem confident they can be the second.
content: The Miami Heat would be the first to assess their path to this late stage of the season as imperfect. Pretty much everything has posed a challenge. The injuries. The losses. Even their experience in the play-in bracket — a loss followed by a come-from-behind win — seems apocryphal, or at least true to form, now that they are facing the Denver Nuggets in the N.B.A. finals.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Flavelle and Adriana Zehbrauskas
title: Arizona, Low on Water, Weighs Taking It From the Sea. In Mexico.
description: A $5 billion plan to desalinate seawater in Mexico and pipe it to Phoenix is testing the notion that desert cities can keep growing as the Earth warms.
content: Fifty miles south of the U.S. border, at the edge of a city on the Gulf of California, a few acres of dusty shrubs could determine the future of Arizona.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: SATURDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlen’s weekly humor column, “Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paula Span
title: Hospice Is a Profitable Business, but Nonprofits Mostly Do a Better Job
description: Nearly three-quarters of hospice organizations are now for-profit. Complaints of fraud and profiteering are growing.
content: In the nearly 20 years that Megan Stainer worked in nursing homes in and around Detroit, she could almost always tell which patients near death were receiving care from nonprofit hospice organizations and which from for-profit hospices.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sydney Bean
title: How a Scratch-Off Lottery Ticket Helped Me Become a Homeowner at 22
description: Sydney Bean was young, broke and tolerating a bad roommate to make ends meet. Then she won the lottery.
content: Our downstairs neighbors had been trying to get us evicted.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eleanor Lutz, Charlie Smart and Mika Gröndahl
title: Where Documents Were Found at Mar-a-Lago
description: These diagrams show the rooms at Donald J. Trump’s residence where prosecutors say he kept sensitive government documents.
content: These diagrams show the rooms at Donald J. Trump’s residence where prosecutors say he kept sensitive government documents.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nailah Morgan
title: Video Shows Rescue of 4 Children After 40 Days in Colombian Jungle
description: The four siblings had been missing after a plane they were traveling in crashed in the Colombian rainforest in May. Rescuers first found the bodies of the three adults who died in the crash, and then launched a search for the children.
content: The four siblings had been missing after a plane they were traveling in crashed in the Colombian rainforest in May. Rescuers first found the bodies of the three adults who died in the crash, and then launched a search for the children.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: Biden Denounces Wave of Laws Targeting L.G.B.T.Q. Americans
description: President Biden told Pride Month revelers that his administration would work to counter the “callous” and “cynical” bills that have recently passed in many Republican-led states.
content: President Biden told Pride Month revelers that his administration would work to counter the “callous” and “cynical” bills that have recently passed in many Republican-led states.
source.name: The New York Times
